At 17:49 02/09/2004, you wrote

>In the usual GA view of evolution, the issue of genes that are
>functionally dependent being inherited together seems to be
>considered significant.

Talking about "genetic" techniques in general, there's two related phenomena:

1) being able to draw equivalences between different genomes during 
crossover (always crossing "like with like")
2) functionally related genes moving together.

It's 1 which is the really important point.  Most approaches to GP, for 
example, don't have any way of doing this, they just cross random nodes 
with other random nodes.  This leads to terrible performance as soon as you 
get away from the arena of "trivial" problems.  One of the best things 
about NEAT (IMHO) is that innovation numbers are a really direct solution 
to this.

>   However, I question whether this is really
>a major problem in nature or NEAT?  Since crossover for the most
>part takes place in a single species, and two organisms in the same
>species more or less have the same set of genes, the issue of
>different building blocks being broken apart from the parents to the
>offspring seems overblown.  Of course, if a duck mated with a pig,
>it would be a huge problem to make sure the duck genes largely stuck
>together.  However, why is this such a concern when a duck mates
>with a duck?

In nature, I think the idea is that over very long periods of time (e.g. 
periods where we can watch 1/2 dozen new species arise), then the genome 
does get shuffled appreciably, and over these long periods, putting 
functionally related genes together is useful.

((Another angle is that some of these groups of functional genes descend 
from a single ancestral gene, so they may be together, merely because they 
never moved apart...))

For NEAT, I don't think that Colin or I were suggesting any failing the way 
innovation numbers already cover this.  I think we were just toying with 
the idea that if you were working on a problem that could be separated into 
discrete "modules", then somehow arranging for a module to be (mostly) 
inherited as a single unit might be useful.  E.g. so that if several rival 
versions of the module were in play, they could be readily shuffled 
throughout the population and tested in the context of all available 
genomes, without being disrupted by every crossover.

It is a sobering thought, that nature does seem to do a lot of 
optimizations which only make sense in terms of having "evolved to evolve" 
(e2e).  And many of the more interesting advances that we are easing up to 
(modules, indirect representations...) are starting to look like e2e.  If 
evolving to solve a problem domain is slow, then features evolving to aid 
the evolution (such as moving or relabelling blocks of genes) must be 
meta-slow.  Now where did I put that peta-flop processor...
